unnormalised: Shoppers in Delhi are feeling the pinch, bhai! Prices of essentials are skyrocketing, especially at local kirana stores. A 1-kg bag of sugar now costs ₹45, up from ₹38 just last month. Dal prices have also seen a jump; Moong dal is selling at ₹120 per kg, a ₹15 increase. And don't even get me started on tomatoes! They're touching ₹80/kg in some areas!
normalised: Shoppers in Delhi are feeling the pinch, bhai! Prices of essentials are skyrocketing, especially at local kirana stores. A one kilogram bag of sugar now costs rupee forty five, up from rupee thirty eight just last month. Dal prices have also seen a jump; Moong dal is selling at rupee one hundred and twenty per kilogram, a rupee fifteen increase. And don't even get me started on tomatoes! They're touching rupee eighty per kilogram in some areas!

unnormalised: It’s not just groceries; even clothes are getting pricier. A basic cotton saree at Lajpat Nagar market is now around ₹800, whereas it used to be ₹650 a few weeks back. Ready-made shirts for men are up by ₹100-₹150, depending on the brand. My cousin was telling me he bought a shirt for ₹750 that he could have gotten for ₹600 last month.
normalised: It’s not just groceries; even clothes are getting pricier. A basic cotton saree at Lajpat Nagar market is now around rupee eight hundred, whereas it used to be rupee six hundred and fifty a few weeks back. Ready-made shirts for men are up by rupee one hundred to rupee one hundred and fifty, depending on the brand. My cousin was telling me he bought a shirt for rupee seven hundred and fifty that he could have gotten for rupee six hundred last month.

unnormalised: Online retailers aren't immune either. Amazon and Flipkart are showing increased prices across several categories. A Samsung Galaxy M31, which was available for ₹14999 during the Diwali sale, is now listed at ₹16499. Even the humble Bluetooth speaker has gone up by ₹200-₹300!
normalised: Online retailers aren't immune either. Amazon and Flipkart are showing increased prices across several categories. A Samsung Galaxy M thirty one, which was available for rupee fourteen thousand nine hundred and ninety nine during the Diwali sale, is now listed at rupee sixteen thousand four hundred and ninety nine. Even the humble Bluetooth speaker has gone up by rupee two hundred to rupee three hundred!

unnormalised: “Everything is so costly these days,” says Mrs. Sharma from Karol Bagh. “I used to get my monthly groceries for around ₹5000, now it's easily crossing ₹6000! I’m having to cut back on certain items.” A similar sentiment is echoed by Mr. Khan, a shopkeeper in Chandni Chowk. "The wholesale prices have gone up, so we have no choice but to increase the retail prices as well."
normalised: “Everything is so costly these days,” says Missus Sharma from Karol Bagh. “I used to get my monthly groceries for around rupee five thousand, now it's easily crossing rupee six thousand! I’m having to cut back on certain items.” A similar sentiment is echoed by Mister Khan, a shopkeeper in Chandni Chowk. "The wholesale prices have gone up, so we have no choice but to increase the retail prices as well."

unnormalised: Fuel prices, of course, are playing a major role. Petrol is hovering around ₹105 per liter, which directly impacts transportation costs. This, in turn, leads to higher prices for everything, from vegetables to electronic goods. Auto-rickshaw fares are also up; a short ride that used to cost ₹30 is now ₹40.
normalised: Fuel prices, of course, are playing a major role. Petrol is hovering around rupee one hundred and five per liter, which directly impacts transportation costs. This, in turn, leads to higher prices for everything, from vegetables to electronic goods. Auto-rickshaw fares are also up; a short ride that used to cost rupee thirty is now rupee forty.

unnormalised: Economists are attributing the price rise to a combination of factors, including rising global commodity prices, supply chain disruptions, and increased demand following the pandemic. The RBI is expected to review the situation in its next monetary policy meeting. Meanwhile, consumers are advised to shop around and look for deals to mitigate the impact on their wallets.
normalised: Economists are attributing the price rise to a combination of factors, including rising global commodity prices, supply chain disruptions, and increased demand following the pandemic. The R-B-I is expected to review the situation in its next monetary policy meeting. Meanwhile, consumers are advised to shop around and look for deals to mitigate the impact on their wallets.

unnormalised: So, next time you're out shopping, be prepared to shell out a bit more. And remember, bargain hard! Every rupee saved counts in these times. Happy shopping, but also, happy saving!
